title.narrative: IDH Landscapes Program

description.narrative: IDH has focused the work of the landscape program on the concept of PPI: Production-Protection-Inclusion. IDH is implementing this concept through the development of PPI compacts in 11 landscapes in seven countries. These are agreements between public, private and civil society parties to enhance sustainable productive land and secure livelihoods in exchange for natural resource conservation. IDH convenes coalitions that develop these compacts. The compacts are based on participatory land-use planning, whereby land for production (increasing productivity), livelihoods (income diversification, resilience, access to markets) and protection (forest, water, soil) is clearly identified, and their related uses are agreed on by the landscape stakeholders and recognized by local and national governments. The compacts also include goals for each of the PPI components, a time-bound plan of action, clear definition of roles and responsibilities, and a budget for implementation. The compacts are the basis for the PPI Fund and other investors to invest in the landscapes, as well as the basis for regional sourcing by supply chain companies. This will result in coalitions that are self-sustaining, are linked to markets, and prove the business case for landscape-level interventions and investments.

receiver-org.narrative: Public and private organizations and partners associated with IDH through signed contracts and agreements for the development and implementation of specific activities and projects in the program sectors that IDH operates in.

Public and private organizations and partners associated with IDH through signed contracts and agreements for the development and implementation of specific activities and projects in the program sectors that IDH operates in.

Public and private organizations and partners associated with IDH through signed contracts and agreements for the development and implementation of specific activities and projects in the program sectors that IDH operates in.

title.narrative: Result Area 3 - Improved field-level sustainability
# of producers/workers/community members trained on key subjects for sustainable production, environmental and social sustainability issues

description.narrative: It is important to capture the following information: The number of producers or workers or community members trained; Split by gender; The number and frequency of individual training events The topic of the training

comment.narrative: One of our 2019 projects contributed significantly to the high number of farmers trained (almost 1,100 farmers were trained on soil and water conservation, apiculture, and good agricultural practices within this project). The implementing partner has a good network of farmers and trainers.

title.narrative: Adoption rate by producers/workers/ community members of improved practices

description.narrative: Measurement takes place 6 months after the training took place, performed by the Implementing Partner (guidance from POs is needed);Typical approaches look at 3-5 key practices that drive productivity, quality, safety or natural resource conservation or restoration practices. These should be defined specifically for each crop/program including specific criteria for adoption. Data collection could be based on a combination of on farm registration via farmer field books and observations in the field on a sample basis.

title.narrative: Number of hectares where protection and restoration interventions are implemented

description.narrative: Number of hectares, type of ecosystem protected (e.g. forest/peatland/grassland), quality of the ecosystem protected (e.g. HCV/HCS area); Type of protection and/or restoration activity. It should include as much as possible information on the effectiveness of the protection and restoration measures

comment.narrative: Additional degraded land contiguous to a plot already under protection was put under protection as well.

title.narrative: Number of hectares where sustainable production/farm rehabilitation/sustainable intensification are implemented

description.narrative: Number of hectares, type of ecosystem protected (e.g. forest/peatland/grassland), quality of the ecosystem protected (e.g. HCV/HCS area); type of protection and/or restoration activity. It should include as much as possible information on the effectiveness of the protection and restoration measures, i.e. when the statistics are available, add the % of illegal deforestation in the area. This will have to be tracked every year, to measure effectiveness of activities aimed at reducing illegal deforestation in the landscape; for forest restoration activities, track the survival rate of planted seedlings. This will have to be tracked every year, to measure effectiveness of the restoration activity.

comment.narrative: Good agricultural practices project with smallholders planned to be completed by 2018 was extended. As a result, additional farmland was put under sustainable intensification.

title.narrative: # of trainers, auditors and/or government staff trained in the program

description.narrative: Several programs have indicated they will develop curricula or guidance for service delivery or extension of good practices. This indicator looks at whether this is being achieved, and whether the next step is taken, being the training of trainers and auditors to use these deliverables.

comment.narrative: Government staff were trained on a needs basis. It was not possible to assess the knowledge gap before the projects started. Once the projects started, gaps were identified and training given to government staff.

title.narrative: Volume of sustainably produced production

description.narrative: The indicator is meant to give insights about the volume of certified and/ or verified sustainable commodity production achieved by the third parties’ participants in the IDH program and/or directly benefited by the IDH program interventions

title.narrative: Number of processing facilities with sustainable production practices and social standards applied

description.narrative: The indicator measures the uptake of more sustainable/good practices at processing facilities, these include production/processing, social and environmental practices. It also provides evidence for the effectiveness of trainings, knowledge exchange and awareness raising.

comment.narrative: 1 packhouse is under GLOBALGAP standard quality management system

title.narrative: # of developed infrastructure facilities

description.narrative: The number, type, and function of infrastructure facilities developed that are instrumental in achieving environmental protection or sustainable commodity production in the landscape

comment.narrative: Due to the late start of one of our projects, there was a delay in the construction of soil and water conservation structures. The 2019 target could not be reached. These activities have started in 2020.
Scaling up of the solid waste management pilot

title.narrative: Farmland area where trained practices are applied

description.narrative: This indicator measures the area where the trained skills have been applied as a result of specific activities implemented in the program (awareness raising, training, new service delivery model etc.).

title.narrative: Result Area 1 - Change in business practice
Private sector (sustainability) investments in the program

description.narrative: The actual realized eligible private sector investments per program (in €)

title.narrative: Sustainability embedded at corporate level

description.narrative: Qualitative description about the embeddedness of sustainability at corporate level of companies/industry organizations/business platforms (this description should provide information on what have changed over the last reporting period in terms of their approach towards sustainability issues, including responsible sourcing and Protection Producdtion Inclusion criteria in case of the landscapes programs)

comment.narrative: Through IDH’s landscape program and co-funding, 48 members of the Meki-Batu Fruits and Vegetables Farmers’ Cooperative Union have been certified for GLOBALG.A.P. for the first time in Ethiopia.

title.narrative: Business cases developed within the IDH program to show the potential of sustainable practices

description.narrative: The number and description of business cases that have been developed within the IDH program to demonstrate to the private sector the potential of sustainable practices adopted and implemented by other organizations

comment.narrative: 1. Water allocatio plan 2. Responsible agrochemical use through implementing GLOBALG.A.P. certification for smallholders
1. SDM for value chain development for smallholders in fruit and vegetables to link with companies, 2. Business case and model developed for community-centered commercial forestry

title.narrative: IDH participation in relevant landscape and or commodity platforms

description.narrative: The role of IDH landscape programs in relevant platforms, round tables, initiatives and coalitions that are addressing sustainability issues, sector transformation, responsible sourcing etc.

comment.narrative: One in Ziway landscape and another in Lake Tana catchment (Kunzila), One Water stewardship leaders’ forum and masterclass

title.narrative: Result Area 2 - Improved sector governance
Representation and commitment of key-stakeholders in multi-stakeholder processes or coalitions

description.narrative: The indicator score is provided by a self-assessment performed by all stakeholders that are involved in the multi-stakeholder processes associated with the program or landscape. On an annual basis, all stakeholders that are active in the processes receive a request to complete a brief electronic questionnaire. The assessment is done through a set of statements focusing on the satisfaction, representation and commitment of the multi-stakeholder processes and coalitions as part of the IDH programs.

title.narrative: Satisfaction about the effectiveness of multi-stakeholder processes or coalitions associated with the program

description.narrative: The perceived satisfaction by the participating stakeholders (i.e. private sector, government, NGOs) of the multi-stakeholder process or coalitions in which they participate.

title.narrative: Landscape plans developed and operationalized

description.narrative: The identification and stage of development of plans that are developed by a coalition of stakeholders in the landscape in which IDH operates.

comment.narrative: Assist national government / EPMHACA to develop local GAP code; assist Oromia regional government on developing roadmap for corporate social responsibility (requested)

title.narrative: Changes at policy and regulatory level contributing to increased sustainability of commodity production and improved management of natural resources

description.narrative: Qualitative description explaining the background and progress of the changes in policies, regulations, and/or enforcement of these as a result of IDH interventions

comment.narrative: An action plan for the development of a Water Allocation Plan in Ziway-Shalla sub-basin was drawn up through collaboration between Rift Valley Lakes Basin Authority and IDH. Mitigation of deforestation, responsible agrochemical use and smallholder Inclusion were all impacted. An impact area relevant to the landscape but not in the IDH impact themes is sustainable water management. Rift Valley Lakes Basin Authority (RVLBA) will be able to plan, manage and administer the water resources’ quantity and quality of the sub basin equitably and sustainably for all current and future water users.
Assist national government / EPMHACA to develop local GAP code; assist Oromia regional government on developing roadmap for corporate social responsibility (requested)
